xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls if every website will load into its own process.
Disabled (0): Doesn't turn off site isolation, but it lets users opt out.
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled (1)

controls:safeguard.title: Ensure Adequate Audit Log Storage
Ensure Backups Have At least One Non-Continuously Addressable Destination

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Chrome will load each website in its own process. Even if a site bypasses the same-origin policy, the extra security will help stop the site from stealing your data from another website.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Polices\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Require Site Isolation for every site
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

If the policy is enabled, each site will run in its own process which will cause the system to use more memory. You might want to look at the Enable Site Isolation for specified origins policy setting to get the best of both worlds isolation and limited impact for users by using Enable Site Isolation for specified origins with a list of the sites you want to isolate.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Force Google SafeSearch' is set to 'Enabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting ensures that web search results with Google are performed with SafeSearch set to always active. Disabled means SafeSearch in Google Search is not enforced.
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled (1)

controls:safeguard.title: Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters
Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Allowing search results to present sites that may have malicious content should be prohibited to help ensure users do not accidentally visit sites that are more prone to malicious content including spyware, adware, and viruses.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to Enabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Force Google SafeSearch
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Users search results will be filtered and content such as adult text, videos and images will not be shown.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Notify a user that a browser relaunch or device restart is recommended or required' is set to 'Enabled: Show a recurring prompt to the user indication that a relaunch is required'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome can notify users that it must be restarted to apply a pending update once the notification period defined by the recommendation Set the time period for update notifications is passed.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Show a recurring prompt to the user indicating that a relaunch is recommended (1)
Show a recurring prompt to the user indicating that a relaunch is required (2)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Disabled : Google Chrome indicates to the user that a relaunch is needed via subtle changes to its menu.
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled with a value of Show a recurring prompt to the user indicating that a relaunch is required (2)

controls:safeguard.title: Perform Automated Application Patch Management
Deploy Automated Software Patch Management Tools

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The end-user will receive a notification informing them that an update has been applied and that the browser must be restarted in order for the update to be completed. Once updates have been pushed by the organization it is pertinent that the update is applied as soon as possible. Enabling this notification will ensure that users restart their browser in a timely fashion.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled: Show a recurring prompt to the user indicating that a relaunch is required :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Polices\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Notify a user that a browser relaunch or device restart is recommended or required
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

A recurring warning will be shown to the user indicating that a browser relaunch will be forced once the notification period passes. The user's session is restored after the relaunch of Google Chrome.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Proxy settings' is set to 'Enabled' and does not contain "ProxyMode": "auto_detect"

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome offers the functionality to configure the proxy settings by automatic discovery using WPAD (Web Proxy Auto-Discovery Protocol). Setting this configures the proxy settings for Chrome and ARC-apps, which ignore all proxy-related options specified from the command line.
Disabled (0): Lets users choose their proxy settings.
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled and the value of ProxyMode is not set to auto_detect

controls:safeguard.title: Perform Application Layer Filtering
Deploy Application Layer Filtering Proxy Server

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Attackers may abuse the WPAD auto-config functionality to supply computers with a PAC file that specifies a rogue web proxy under their control.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, make sure the following UI path is set to 'Enabled' and the value of ProxyMode is not set to auto_detect :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Polices\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Proxy settings
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If the policy is enabled, the proxy configuration will no longer be discovered using WPAD.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Require online OCSP/CRL checks for local trust anchors' is set to 'Enabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome performs revocation checking for server certificates that successfully validate and are signed by locally-installed CA certificates. If Google Chrome is unable to obtain revocation status information, such certificates will be treated as revoked ('hard-fail').
Disabled : Google Chrome uses existing online revocation-checking settings.
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled (1)

controls:safeguard.title: Explicitly Not Mapped
Explicitly Not Mapped

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Certificates shall always be validated.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Polices\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Require online OCSP/CRL checks for local trust anchors
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

A revocation check will be performed for server certificates that successfully validate and are signed by locally-installed CA certificates. if the OCSP server goes down, then this will hard-fail and prevent browsing to those sites.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Set the time period for update notifications' is set to 'Enabled: 86400000'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome allows to set the time period, in milliseconds, over which users are notified that it must be relaunched to apply a pending update.
If not set, or Disabled , the default period of 604800000 milliseconds (7 days) is used.
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled with value 86400000 (1 day)

controls:safeguard.title: Perform Automated Application Patch Management
Deploy Automated Software Patch Management Tools

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: This setting is a notification for the end-user informing them that an update has been applied and that the browser must be restarted in order for the update to be completed. Once updates have been pushed by the organization it is pertinent that said update takes effect as soon as possible. Enabling this notification will ensure users restart the browser in a timely fashion.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled: 5265C00 (86400000 in Hexadecimal):
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Polices\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Set the time period for update notifications
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
After this time period, the user will be repeatedly informed of the need for an update until a Browser restart is completed.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Allow Web Authentication requests on sites with broken TLS certificates' Is Disabled

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This policy setting controls the WebAuthn API and its interaction with sites that have a broken TLS certificate. It can be configured to either:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Disabled (0): Do not allow WebAuthn API requests on sites with broken TLS certificates.
Enabled (1): Allow WebAuthn API requests on sites with broken TLS certificates.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: If the value for AllowWebAuthnWithBrokenTlsCerts is not changed from the default, it will behave as it is disabled.xempt.

controls:safeguard.title: Encrypt Sensitive Data in Transit
Train Workforce on Data Handling Best Practices

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Setting this policy will block the ability to authenticate to any website that does not have a valid TLS certificate since the identity of the site cannot be verified.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Allow Web Authentication requests on sites with broken TLS certificates.
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
There should be no user impact.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Allow reporting of domain reliability related data' Is Disabled

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls the defaults for clipboard permission access from sites. It can be configured to either:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Disabled (0): Never send domain reliability data to Google
Enabled (1): Domain Reliability data may be sent to Google depending on Chrome User Metrics (UMA) policy

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: If the value for DomainReliabilityAllowed is not changed from the default, it will behave as it is enabled.

controls:safeguard.title: Use DNS Filtering Services
Maintain Inventory of Administrative Accounts

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Setting this policy to disabled can stop any accidental data leakage.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google Chrome\Allow reporting of domain reliability related data
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
There should be no impact on the user.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable TLS Encrypted ClientHello' Is Enabled

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls the defaults for using Encrypted ClientHello (ECH). ECH is an extension to TLS and encrypts the initial handshake with a website that can only be decrypted by that website. Google Chrome may, or may not, use ECH based on 3 factors: sever support, HTTPS DNS record availability, or rollout status. It can be configured to either:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Disabled (0): Disable the TLS Encrypted ClientHello experiment
Enabled (1): Enable the TLS Encrypted ClientHello experiment

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: If the value for EncryptedClientHelloEnabled is not changed from the default, it will behave as it is enabled.

controls:safeguard.title: Encrypt Sensitive Data in Transit
Train Workforce on Data Handling Best Practices

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Previously all handshakes were in the open and could expose sensitive information like the name of the website that you are connecting to. Setting this policy will allow Google Chrome to use an encrypted hello, or handshake, with a website where it is supported, thus not exposing sensitive information.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enable TLS Encrypted ClientHello
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
There should be no impact on the user.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Determines whether the built-in certificate verifier will enforce constraints encoded into trust anchors loaded from the platform trust store' Is Enabled

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls constraints encoded into trust anchors loaded from the platform trust store. It can be configured to either:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Disabled (0): Do not enforce constraints in locally added trust anchors
Enabled (1): Enforce constraints in locally added trust anchors

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: If the value for EnforceLocalAnchorConstraintsEnabled is not changed from the default, it will behave as if it is enabled.

controls:safeguard.title: Explicitly Not Mapped
Explicitly Not Mapped

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Setting this policy will not allow access to any sites that do not enforce constraints.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Determines whether the built-in certificate verifier will enforce constraints encoded into trust anchors loaded from the platform trust store.
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Enabling this might cause certain internal sites to not properly load until they are updated.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Keep browsing data when creating enterprise profile by default' Is Enabled

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls keeping existing browser data when an enterprise profile is created. It can be configured to either:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Disabled (0): Do not check the option to keep existing browsing data by default
Enabled (1): Check the option to keep existing browsing data by default

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: If the value for EnterpriseProfileCreationKeepBrowsingData is not changed from the default, it will behave as if it is enabled.
Note: Unlike other policy settings, the user does get to decide whether or not to keep any existing browsing data when creating an enterprise profile.

controls:safeguard.title: Explicitly Not Mapped
Explicitly Not Mapped

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Setting this policy gives the user the option to keep any previous browsing data after setting up an enterprise profile.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Keep browsing data when creating enterprise profile by default
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This should have no effect on the user.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Allow file or directory picker APIs to be called without prior user gesture' Is Disabled

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls the ability for showOpenFilePicker() , showSaveFilePicker() , and showDirectoryPicker() web APIs to be called without user interaction.
If the value for FileOrDirectoryPickerWithoutGestureAllowedForOrigins is not changed from the default, it will behave as if it is disabled.

controls:safeguard.title: Establish and Maintain a Remediation Process
Apply Host-based Firewalls or Port Filtering

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Setting this policy would allow the URLs selected to call the showOpenFilePicker() , showSaveFilePicker() , and showDirectoryPicker() web APIs without any user gesture/interaction. This policy does not need to be set for this reason.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Allow file or directory picker APIs to be called without prior user gesture
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Disabling this policy should have no impact on the user.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable Google Search Side Panel' Is Disabled

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls the Google Search Side Panel. It can be configured to either:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Disabled (0): Disable Google Search Side Panel on all web pages
Enabled (1): Enable Google Search Side Panel on all web pages

controls:safeguard.title: Use DNS Filtering Services
Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Setting this policy will not allow the Google Search Side Panel on any webpages.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enable Google Search Side Panel
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This should have no user impact.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Http Allowlist' Is Properly Configured

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting allows administrators to list specific sites that will not be upgraded to HTTPS and will not show an error interstitial if HTTPS-First Mode is enabled.
Note: Wildcards ( * , [*] , etc.) are not allowed in the URL listings.

controls:safeguard.title: Allowlist Authorized Scripts
Integrate Software and Hardware Asset Inventories

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Setting this policy allows organizations to maintain access to servers that do not support HTTPS without having to disable HTTPS-First mode or HTTPS Upgrades.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled and set Show to the approved URLs:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\HTTP Allowlist
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This should not have an impact on the user.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable automatic HTTPS upgrades' Is Enabled

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls the ability for Google Chrome to upgrade to HTTPS from HTTP while navigating to certain sites. It can be configured to either:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Disabled (0): Disable HTTPS Upgrades
Enabled (1): HTTPS Upgrades may be applied depending on feature launch status

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: If the value for HttpsUpgradesEnabled is not changed from the default, it will behave as if it is enabled.

controls:safeguard.title: Securely Dispose of Data
Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Enabling this setting will upgrade the connection to a site from HTTP to HTTPS where available, verifying the identity of the site visited.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enable automatic HTTPS upgrades
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This should have no impact on the user.
Note: If there are internal sites/servers that use HTTP only, set those in the policy HttpAllowlist

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Insecure Hashes in TLS Handshakes Enabled' Is Disabled

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls the ability for Google Chrome to allow legacy or insecure hashes during the TLS handshake. It can be configured to either:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Disabled (0): Do Not Allow Insecure Hashes in TLS Handshakes
Enabled (1): Allow Insecure Hashes in TLS Handshakes

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: If the value for InsecureHashesInTLSHandshakesEnabled is not changed from the default, it will behave as if it is enabled.

controls:safeguard.title: Encrypt Sensitive Data in Transit
Train Workforce on Data Handling Best Practices

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Setting this policy to disabled will block Google Chrome from using insecure hashes. Using insecure, or legacy, hashes could allow sensitive data to be exposed.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Insecure Hashes in TLS Handshakes Enabled
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Users would be blocked from visiting sites that do not support more secure hashes.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable Renderer App Container' Is Enabled

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls the ability for Google Chrome to allow the Render App Container sandbox to be used while navigating to certain sites. It can be configured to either:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Disabled (0): Disable the Renderer App Container sandbox
Enabled (1): Enable the Renderer App Container sandbox

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: If the value for RendererAppContainerEnabled is not changed from the default, it will behave as if it is enabled.

controls:safeguard.title: Use DNS Filtering Services
Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Disabling this policy would weaken the sandbox that Google Chrome uses for the renderer process, and will have a detrimental effect on the security and stability of the browser. This policy needs to be enabled to maintain security and stability.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enable Renderer App Container
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This would only impact users if there is third-party software that must run inside renderer processes.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable strict MIME type checking for worker scripts' Is Enabled

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls the ability for Google Chrome to upgrade to HTTPS from HTTP while navigating to certain sites. It can be configured to either:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Disabled (0): Scripts for workers (Web Workers, Service Workers, etc.) use lax MIME type checking. Worker scripts with legacy MIME types, like text/ascii, will work.
Enabled (1): Scripts for workers (Web Workers, Service Workers, etc.) require a JavaScript MIME type, like text/javascript. Worker scripts with legacy MIME types, like text/ascii, will be rejected.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: If the value for StrictMimetypeCheckForWorkerScriptsEnabled is not changed from the default, it will behave as if it is enabled.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Setting this policy will require worker scripts to use more secure and strict JavaScript MIME types and ones with legacy MIME Types will be rejected.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enable strict MIME type checking for worker scripts
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This should have no impact on users.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'Allow remote debugging' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This policy setting controls whether users may use remote debugging. This feature allows remote debugging of live content on a Windows 10 or later device from a Windows or macOS computer.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled .

controls:safeguard.title: Establish and Maintain a Remediation Process
Manage Access Control for Remote Assets

notes:notes.xhtml:p: I copied/adjusted this rule from MS Edge, rule 1.41

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Disabling remote debugging enhances security and protects applications from unauthorized access. Some attack tools can exploit this feature to extract information, or to insert malicious code.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Allow remote debugging
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Note: This Group Policy path may not exist by default. It is provided by the Group Policy template google.admx/adml that can be downloaded from: Download Chrome Browser for Your Business - Chrome Enterprise .
Impact:
Users will not be able access the remote debugging feature in Google Chrome.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This section contains recommendations that help improve user privacy. Organizations should review these settings and any potential impacts to ensure they make sense within the environment since they restrict some browser functionality.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Default cookies setting' is set to 'Enabled: Keep cookies for the duration of the session'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: When leaving the setting _RestoreOnStartup _unset results in the use of _DefaultCookiesSetting _for all sites, if it's set. If _DefaultCookiesSetting _is not set, the user's personal setting applies.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Disabled (0, user's personal setting applies)
Allow all sites to set local data (1)
Do not allow any site to set local data (2)
Keep cookies for the duration of the session (4)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled with a value of Keep cookies for the duration of the session (4)

NOTE: If the RestoreOnStartup setting is set to restore URLs from previous sessions this setting will not be respected and cookies will be stored permanently for those sites. An example of those URLs are SSO or intranet sites.

controls:safeguard.title: Explicitly Not Mapped
Explicitly Not Mapped

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Permanently stored cookies may be used for malicious intent.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled: Keep cookies for the duration of the session :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Content Settings\Default cookies setting
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is enabled, cookies will be cleared when the session closes.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Default geolocation setting' is set to 'Enabled: Do not allow any site to track the users' physical location'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome supports tracking a user's physical location using GPS, data about nearby Wi-Fi access points or cellular signal sites/towers (even if youre not using them), and your computers IP.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Disabled (0, same as 3)
Allow sites to track the users' physical location (1)
Do not allow any site to track the users' physical location (2)
Ask whenever a site wants to track the users' physical location (3)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled with a value Do not allow any site to track the users' physical location (2)

controls:safeguard.title: Explicitly Not Mapped
Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: From a privacy point of view it is not desirable to submit indicators regarding the location of the device, since the processing of this information cannot be determined. Furthermore, this may leak information about the network infrastructure around the device.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled: Do not allow any site to track the users' physical location :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Content Settings\Default geolocation setting
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, chrome will no longer send data about nearby Wi-Fi access points or cellular signal sites/towers (even if youre not using them), and your computers IP address to Google.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable Google Cast' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Cast can send the contents of tabs, sites, or the desktop from the browser to a remote display and sound system.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)

controls:safeguard.title: Uninstall or Disable Unnecessary Services on Enterprise Assets and Software
Ensure Only Approved Ports, Protocols and Services Are Running

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Google Cast may send the contents of tabs, sites, or the desktop from the browser to non-trusted devices on the local network segment.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Google Cast\Enable Google Cast
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this is disabled, Google Cast is not activated and the toolbar icon is not shown.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Allow websites to query for available payment methods' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting allows you to set whether a website can check to see if the user has payment methods saved.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)

controls:safeguard.title: Use DNS Filtering Services
Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Saving payment information in Google Chrome could lead to sensitive data being leaked and used for non-legitimate purposes.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Allow websites to query for available payment methods.
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Websites will be unable to query whether payment information within Google Chrome is available.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Block third party cookies' is set to 'Enabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Chrome allows cookies to be set by web page elements that are not from the domain in the user's address bar. Enabling this feature prevents third party cookies from being set.
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled (1)

controls:safeguard.title: Use DNS Filtering Services
Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Blocking third-party cookies can help protect a user's privacy by eliminating a number of website tracking cookies.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Block third party cookies
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Enabling this setting prevents cookies from being set by web page elements that are not from the domain that is in the browser's address bar.

NOTE : Third Party Cookies and Tracking Protection are required for many business critical websites, including Microsoft 365 web apps (Office 365), SalesForce, and SAP Analytics Cloud. If these, or similar services, are needed by the organization, then this setting can be Disabled.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Browser sign in settings' is set to 'Enabled: Disabled browser sign-in'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome offers to sign in with your Google account and use account-related services like Chrome sync. It is possible to sign in to Google Chrome with a Google account to use services like synchronization, and can also be used for configuration and management of the browser.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Disable browser sign-in (0)
Enable browser sign-in (1)
Force users to sign-in to use the browser (2)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled with a value of Disable browser sign-in (0)
NOTE: If an organization is a Google Workspace Enterprise customer, they will want to leave this setting enabled so that users can sign in with Google accounts.

controls:safeguard.title: Use DNS Filtering Services
Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Since external accounts are unmanaged and potentially used to access several private computer systems and many different websites, connecting accounts via sign-in poses a security risk for the company. It interferes with the corporate management mechanisms, as well as permits an unwanted leak of corporate information and possible mixture with private, non-company data.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled: Disable browser sign-in
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Browser sign in settings
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is configured, the user cannot sign in to the browser and use Google account-based services like Chrome sync.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Control how Chrome Cleanup reports data to Google' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: If the setting is Disabled , the results of the cleanup will not be shared with Google regardless of the value of SafeBrowsingExtendedReportingEnabled .
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)
NOTE: This setting is not available on Windows instances that are not joined to a Microsoft Active Directory domain.

controls:safeguard.title: Use DNS Filtering Services
Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Anonymous crash/usage data can be used to identify people, companies, and information, which can be considered data ex-filtration from company systems.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Control how Chrome Cleanup reports data to Google
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Chrome Cleanup detected unwanted software and will no longer report metadata about the scan to Google.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Disable synchronization of data with Google' is set to 'Enabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome can synchronize browser data using Google-hosted synchronization services. Examples of synced data include, but are not limited to, history and favorites.
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled (1)
NOTE: if your organization allows synchronization of data with Google, then disabling this setting will synchronize saved passwords with Google.

controls:safeguard.title: Use DNS Filtering Services
Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Browser data shall not be synchronized into the Google Cloud.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Disable synchronization of data with Google
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is enabled, browser data will no longer sync with Google across devices/platforms, allowing users to pick up where they left off.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable alternate error pages' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome offers to show suggestions for the page you were trying to reach when it is unable to connect to a web address such as 'Page Not Found'.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)

controls:safeguard.title: Use DNS Filtering Services
Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Using navigation suggestions may leak information about the web site intended to be visited.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enable alternate error pages
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, Chrome will no longer use a web service to help resolve navigation errors.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable deleting browser and download history' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome can delete the browser and download history using the clear browsing data menu.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)

NOTE: Even when this setting is disabled, the browsing and download history aren't guaranteed to be retained. Users can edit or delete the history database files directly, and the browser itself may remove (based on expiration period) or archive any or all history items at any time

controls:safeguard.title: Use DNS Filtering Services
Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If users can delete websites they have visited or files they have downloaded it will be easier for them to hide evidence that they have visited unauthorized or malicious sites.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enable deleting browser and download history
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, browsing and download history cannot be deleted by using the clear browsing data menu.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable predict network actions` is set to 'Enabled: Do not predict actions on any network connection'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome comes with the network prediction feature which provides DNS prefetching, TCP and SSL preconnection, and prerendering of web pages.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Predict network actions on any network connection (0) or (1)
Do not predict network actions on any network connection (2)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled with a value of Do not predict network actions on any network connection (2)

controls:safeguard.title: Explicitly Not Mapped
Explicitly Not Mapped

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Opening connections to resources that may not be used could allow unneeded connections increasing attack surface and in some cases could lead to opening connections to resources which the user did not intend to utilize.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled: Do not predict network actions on any network connection :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enable network prediction
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Users will not be presented with web page predictions.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable or disable spell checking web service' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome can use Google web service to help resolve spelling errors.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)

controls:safeguard.title: Use DNS Filtering Services
Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Information typed in may be leaked to Google's spellcheck web service.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enable or disable spell checking web service
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

After disabling this feature, Chrome no longer sends the entire contents of text fields to Google as you type them. Spell checking can still be performed using a downloaded dictionary. This setting only controls the usage of the online service.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable reporting of usage and crash-related data' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls anonymous reporting of usage and crash-related data about Google Chrome to Google.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)
NOTE: This setting is not available on Windows instances that are not joined to a Microsoft Active Directory domain.

controls:safeguard.title: Use DNS Filtering Services
Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Anonymous crash/usage data can be used to identify people, companies and information, which can be considered data ex-filtration from company systems.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enable reporting of usage and crash-related data
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, this information is not sent to Google.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable Safe Browsing for trusted sources' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome can be adjusted to allow downloads without Safe Browsing checks when the requested file is from a trusted source. Trusted sources can be defined using recommendation 'Configure the list of domains on which Safe Browsing will not trigger warnings'.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)

NOTE: On Microsoft Windows, this functionality is only available on instances that are joined to a Microsoft Active Directory domain, running on Windows 10 Pro, or enrolled in Chrome Browser Cloud Management.

controls:safeguard.title: Use DNS Filtering Services
Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Information requested from trusted sources shall not be sent to Google's safe browsing servers.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enable Safe Browsing for trusted sources
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, files downloaded from intranet resources will not be checked by Google Services.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Enable search suggestions' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome offers suggestions in Google Chrome's omnibox while a user is typing.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)

controls:safeguard.title: Use DNS Filtering Services
Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Using search suggestions may leak information as soon as it is typed/pasted into the omnibox, e.g. passwords, internal webservices, folder structures, etc.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enable search suggestions
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
The user has to send the search request actively by using the search button or hitting "Enter".

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Enable Translate' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting enables Google translation services on Google Chrome.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)

controls:safeguard.title: Use DNS Filtering Services
Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Content of internal web pages may be leaked to Google's translation service.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enable Translate
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
After disabling this feature, the contents of a web page are no longer sent to Google for translation.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable URL-keyed anonymized data collection' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome offers the feature URL-keyed anonymized data collection. This sends URLs of pages the user visits to Google to optimize its services.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)

controls:safeguard.title: Explicitly Not Mapped
Deploy Automated Software Patch Management Tools

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Anonymized data collection shall be disabled, since it is unclear which information exactly is sent to Google.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enable URL-keyed anonymized data collection
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Anonymized data will not be sent to Google to help optimize its services

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This section contains recommendations to help prevent and protect against unwanted loss of data. Organizations should review these settings and any potential impacts to ensure they make sense within the environment, since they restrict some browser functionality.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Allow or deny screen capture' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls whether Google Chrome can use screen-share APIs including web-based online meetings, video, or screen sharing.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)

NOTE: This setting is not considered (and a site will be allowed to use screen-share APIs) if the site matches an origin pattern in any of the following other settings: ScreenCaptureAllowedByOrigins , WindowCaptureAllowedByOrigins , TabCaptureAllowedByOrigins , SameOriginTabCaptureAllowedByOrigins .

controls:safeguard.title: Explicitly Not Mapped
Explicitly Not Mapped

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Allowing screen-share APIs within Google Chrome could potentially allow for sensitive data to be shared via screen captures.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Allow or deny screen capture\Allow or deny screen capture
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

Users will be unable to utilize APIs which support web-based meetings (video conferencing screen sharing), video, and screen capture. This could potentially cause disruption to users who may have utilized these abilities in the past.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Control use of the Serial API' is set to 'Enabled: Do not allow any site to request access to serial ports via the Serial API'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls website access and use of the system serial port.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Do not allow any site to request access to serial ports via the Serial API (2)
Allow sites to ask the user to grant access to a serial port (3)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The recommended state for this setting is: Do not allow any site to request access to serial ports via the Serial API (2)

NOTE: If more granular control is needed (per website) then this setting can be used in combination with the SerialAllowAllPortsForUrls , SerialAskForUrls and SerialBlockedForUrls settings. For example, SerialAllowAllPortsForUrls can be used to allow serial port access to specific sites. Please see the references below for more information.

controls:safeguard.title: Uninstall or Disable Unnecessary Services on Enterprise Assets and Software
Ensure Only Approved Ports, Protocols and Services Are Running

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Preventing access to system serial ports may prevent malicious sites from using these ports and accessing the devices attached.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled: Do not allow any site to request access to serial ports via the Serial API :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Content settings\Control use of the Serial API
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This setting would also prevent legitimate sites from accessing it as well.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Default Sensors Setting' is set to 'Enabled: Do not allow any site to access sensors'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls website access and use of system sensors such as motion and light.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Allow sites to access sensors (1)
Do not allow any site to access sensors (2)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The recommended state for this setting is: Do not allow any site to access sensors (2)
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled with a value of Do not allow any site to access sensors

NOTE: If more granular control is needed (per website) then this setting can be used in combination with the SensorsAllowedForUrls and SensorsBlockedForUrls settings. For example, SensorsAllowedForUrls can be used to allow sensor access to specific sites. Please see the references below for more information.

controls:safeguard.title: Uninstall or Disable Unnecessary Services on Enterprise Assets and Software
Ensure Only Approved Ports, Protocols and Services Are Running

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Preventing access to system sensors may prevent malicious sites from using these sensors for user profiling (OpSec).

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled: Do not allow any site to access sensors :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Content settings\Default sensors setting
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This setting would also prevent legitimate sites from accessing it as well.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Allow clipboard for these sites' Is Configured

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting allows administrators to list specific sites that have access to the clipboard site permissions.
Note: This does not include using keyboard shortcuts. Those are not gated by the clipboard site permission.

controls:safeguard.title: Explicitly Not Mapped
Explicitly Not Mapped

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Setting this policy allows specified URLs to have access to the clipboard site permissions. This will allow the specified sites to have access to data on the clipboard that other sites do not. DefaultClipboardSetting is recommended to be set to disabled , so this list would be the only sites that would have access to the clipboard data.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled and set Show to the approved URLs:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Content settings\Allow clipboard on these sites
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Enforcing this recommendation can cause the clipboard functionality to not work identically for every site.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Block clipboard on these sites' Is Configured

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting allows administrators to list specific sites that do not have access to the clipboard site permissions.
Note: This does not include using keyboard shortcuts. Those are not gated by the clipboard site permission.

controls:safeguard.title: Use DNS Filtering Services
Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Specifying URLs that do not have access to the clipboard site permissions limits data for sites that have access to data on the clipboard, and allows for more sites to have access.

Setting this policy denies specified URLs to have access to the clipboard site permissions. This will limit the specified sites to access the data on the clipboard that other sites do. DefaultClipboardSetting is recommended to be set to disabled , so this list would be a backup to that policy in case it was enabled, left as the default, or removed.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled and set Show to the blocked URLs:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Content settings\Block clipboard on these sites
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Enforcing this recommendation can cause the clipboard functionality to not work identically for every site.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Default clipboard setting' Is 'Enabled' to 'Deny Permissions'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls the defaults for clipboard permission access from sites. It can be configured to either:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Disabled (2): Does not allow access to the clipboard site permission by any site
Enabled (3): Sites ask the user to allow access to the clipboard site permission

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: If the value for DefaultClipboardSetting is not changed from the default, it will behave as if it is enabled. ClipboardAllowedForUrls or ClipboardBlockedForUrls will override this setting for any site that matches the configured URL patterns.
With the setting disabled, organizations will need to set ClipboardAllowedForUrls for any URLs they want to make exempt.

controls:safeguard.title: Use DNS Filtering Services
Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The clipboard stores data, text, and images that are shared between all applications. An organization would disable clipboard access to restrict sites from reading the contents of the clipboard when visiting.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled: Do not allow any site to use the clipboard site permission :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Content settings\Default clipboard setting
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Not allowing sites to have access to the clipboard permission can cause issues with formatting or access to needed images on the clipboard.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Default Window Management permissions setting' Is 'Enabled' to 'Deny Permission'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting can automatically deny access to the window management permissions by sites. It can be configured to either:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Disabled (2): Does not allow access to the Window Management permission by any site
Enabled (3): A site must ask the user any time it wants to access the Window Management permission.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: If the value for DefaultWindowManagementSetting is not changed from the default, it will behave as if it is enabled. WindowManagementAllowedForUrls or WindowManagementBlockedForUrls will override this setting for any site that matches the configured URL patterns.

controls:safeguard.title: Explicitly Not Mapped
Explicitly Not Mapped

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Denying access to Window Management can block rogue sites from opening additional browser windows. By blocking the additional windows, an organization could stop instances of nefarious sites being opened in locations of which the user is unaware.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled and Denies the Window Management permission on all sites by default :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Content settings\Default Window Management permission setting
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Disabling this would take away the functionality of the user to decide what sites get access to the Window Management permission and could impact organizational required URLs.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Allow Window Management permission on these sites' Is Configured

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting can automatically allow access to the window management permissions for specific sites.
If the value for WindowManagementAllowedForUrls is not changed from the default, it will follow the configuration of DefaultWindowManagementSetting .

controls:safeguard.title: Explicitly Not Mapped
Explicitly Not Mapped

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Allowing only specific sites to have access to Window Management will only allow permitted sites to see information about the device's screens, open additional browser windows specifying location, and size of the window.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled and set Show to the approved URLs:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Content settings\Allow Window Management permission on these sites
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Enforcing this recommendation can cause visited sites to not display as intended.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Block Window Management permission on these sites' Is Configured

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting can automatically deny access to the window management permissions for specific sites. It can be configured to either:
If the value for WindowManagementBlockedForUrls is not changed from the default, it will follow the configuration of DefaultWindowManagementSetting .

controls:safeguard.title: Explicitly Not Mapped
Explicitly Not Mapped

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Specifying URLs that do not have access to the window management permissions limits data for sites that have access to data on the clipboard, and allows for more sites to have access.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled and set Show to the blocked URLs:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Content settings\Block Window Management permission on these sites
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Enforcing this recommendation can cause visited sites to not display as intended.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Allow invocation of file selection dialogs' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting allows access to local files by allowing file selection dialogs in Google Chrome.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)

controls:safeguard.title: Allowlist Authorized Scripts
Integrate Software and Hardware Asset Inventories

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Allowing users to import favorites, upload files, and save links could pose potential security risks by allowing data to be uploaded to external sites or by downloading malicious files. By not allowing the file selection dialog, the end-user will not be prompted for uploads/downloads, preventing data exfiltration and possible system infection by malware.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Allow invocation of file selection dialogs
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

If you disable this setting, users will no longer be prompted when performing actions which would trigger a file selection dialog. Instead, the file selection dialog box assumes the user clicked "Cancel". Being as this is not the default behavior, impact to the user will be noticeable, and the user will not be able to upload and download files.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Allow or deny audio capture' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting allows administrators to set whether the end-user is prompted for access to audio capture devices.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Disabled (0): Turns off prompts and audio capture will only work for URLs configured in the AudioCaptureAllowedUrls list.
Enabled (1): With the exception of URLs set in the AudioCaptureAllowedUrls list, users get prompted for audio capture access.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: NOTE: The setting affects all audio input (not just the built-in microphone).
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled

controls:safeguard.title: Use DNS Filtering Services
Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The end-user having the ability to allow or deny audio capture for websites in Google Chrome could open an organization up to a malicious site that may capture proprietary information through the browser. By limiting or disallowing audio capture, it removes the end-user's discretion, leaving it up to the organization which sites are allowed to use this ability.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Allow or deny audio capture
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

If you disable this setting, users will not be prompted for audio devices when using websites which may need this access, such as a web-based conferencing system. If there are sites which access will be allowed, configuration of the AudioCaptureAllowedUrls setting will be necessary.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Allow or deny video capture' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting allows administrators to set whether the end-user is prompted for access to video capture devices.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Disabled (0): Turns off prompts and video capture will only work for URLs configured in the VideoCaptureAllowedUrls list.
Enabled (1): With the exception of URLs set in the VideoCaptureAllowedUrls list, users get prompted for video capture access.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: NOTE: The setting affects all video input (not just the built-in camera).
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)

controls:safeguard.title: Use DNS Filtering Services
Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The end-user having the ability to allow or deny video capture for websites in Google Chrome could open an organization up to a malicious site that may capture proprietary information through the browser. By limiting or disallowing video capture, it removes the end-user's discretion, leaving it up to the organization which sites are allowed to use this ability.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Allow or deny video capture
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

If you disable this setting, users will not be prompted for video devices when using websites which may need this access, such as a web-based conferencing system. If there are sites which access will be allowed, configuration of the VideoCaptureAllowedUrls setting will be necessary.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Allow user feedback' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls whether users are able to utilize the Chrome feedback feature to send feedback, suggestions, and surveys to Google, as well as issue reports.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)

controls:safeguard.title: Use DNS Filtering Services
Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Data should not be shared with third-party vendors in an enterprise managed environment.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Allow user feedback
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Users will not be able to send feedback to Google.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Controls the mode of DNS-over-HTTPS' is set to 'Enabled: DNS-over-HTTPS without insecure fallback'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This controls the mode of the DNS-over-HTTPS resolver. Please note that this setting will only set the default mode for each query. The mode may be overridden for special types of queries, such as requests to resolve a DNS-over-HTTPS server hostname.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Disable DNS-over-HTTPS (off)
Enable DNS-over-HTTPS with insecure fallback (automatic) - Enable DNS-over-HTTPS queries first if a DNS-over-HTTPS server is available and may fallback to sending insecure queries on error.
Enable DNS-over-HTTPS without insecure fallback (secure) - Only send DNS-over-HTTPS queries and will fail to resolve on error.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled with a value of Enable DNS-over-HTTPS without insecure fallback (secure)

Note: When enabling this policy, it is recommended to also configure the DnsOverHttpsTemplates policy so that the URI templates are set. You can find out more information on the DnsOverHttpsTemplates enterprise policy site .

controls:safeguard.title: Encrypt Sensitive Data in Transit
Train Workforce on Data Handling Best Practices

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: DNS over HTTPS (DOH) has a couple primary benefits:

xhtml:li.xhtml:p: Encrypting DNS name resolution traffic helps to hide your online activities, since DoH hides the name resolution requests from the ISP and from anyone listening on intermediary networks.
DoH also helps to prevent DNS spoofing and man-in-the-middle (MitM) attacks.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled: Enable DNS-over-HTTPS without insecure fallback :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Controls the mode of DNS-over-HTTPS
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

Not all DNS providers support DOH, so choice is limited. Also, Enterprises sometimes monitor DNS requests to block access to malicious or inappropriate sites. DNS monitoring can also sometimes be used to detect malware attempting to "phone home." Because DoH encrypts name resolution requests, it can create a security monitoring blind spot.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Enable AutoFill for addresses' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Chrome allows users to auto-complete web forms with saved information such as address or phone number. Disabling this feature will prompt a user to enter all information manually.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)

controls:safeguard.title: Use DNS Filtering Services
Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If an attacker gains access to a user's machine where the user has stored address AutoFill data, information could be harvested.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enable AutoFill for addresses
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, AutoFill will be inaccessible to users.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable AutoFill for credit cards' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Chrome allows users to auto-complete web forms with saved credit card information. Disabling this feature will prompt a user to enter all information manually.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)

controls:safeguard.title: Use DNS Filtering Services
Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If an attacker gains access to a user's machine where the user has stored credit card AutoFill data, information could be harvested.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enable AutoFill for credit cards
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, credit card AutoFill will be inaccessible to users.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Import saved passwords from default browser on first run' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls if saved passwords from the default browser can be imported (on first run and later manually).
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)

controls:safeguard.title: Use DNS Filtering Services
Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: In Chrome, passwords can be stored in plain-text and revealed by clicking the show button next to the password field by going to chrome://settings/passwords/.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Import saved passwords from default browser on first run
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, saved passwords from other browsers are not imported.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'List of types that should be excluded from synchronization' is set to 'Enabled: passwords'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting allows you to specify data types that will be limited/excluded from uploading data to the Google Chrome synchronization service.
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled with the following text value passwords (Case Sensitive)
NOTE: Other settings in addition to passwords can be included based on organizational needs.

controls:safeguard.title: Explicitly Not Mapped
Explicitly Not Mapped

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Storing and sharing information could potentially expose sensitive information including but not limited to user passwords and login information. Allowing this synchronization could also potentially allow an end user to pull corporate data that was synchronized into the cloud to a personal machine.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled: passwords (Case Sensitive):
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\List of types that should be excluded from synchronization
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Password data will not be synchronized with the Google Chrome synchronization service.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Allow or deny screen capture' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: If enabled or not configured (default), a Web page can use screen-share APIs (e.g., getDisplayMedia() or the Desktop Capture extension API) to prompt the user to select a tab, window, or desktop to capture.

controls:safeguard.title: Explicitly Not Mapped
Explicitly Not Mapped

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The end-user having the ability to allow or deny screen capture for websites in Google Chrome could open an organization up to a malicious site that may capture proprietary information through the browser. By limiting or disallowing screen capture, it removes the end-user's discretion, leaving it up to the organization which sites are allowed to use this ability.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Allow or deny screen capture\Allow or deny screen capture
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

When this policy is disabled, any calls to screen-share APIs will fail with an error. This policy is not considered (and a site will be allowed to use screen-share APIs) if the site matches an origin pattern in any of the following policies: ScreenCaptureAllowedByOrigins, WindowCaptureAllowedByOrigins, TabCaptureAllowedByOrigins, SameOriginTabCaptureAllowedByOrigins.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This section contains recommendations to help in post-incident forensics and analysis. Organizations should review these settings and any potential impacts to ensure they make sense within their environment.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Enable guest mode in browser' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls whether a user may utilize guest profiles in Google Chrome.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)

controls:safeguard.title: Use DNS Filtering Services
Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: In a guest profile, the browser doesn't import browsing data from existing profiles, and it deletes browsing data when all guest profiles are closed.

Deleting browser data will delete information that may be important for a computer investigation, and investigators such as Computer Forensics Analysts may not be able to retrieve pertinent information to the investigation.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enable guest mode in browser
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Users will not be able to initiate Guest mode for Google Chrome.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Incognito mode availability' is set to 'Enabled: Incognito mode disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Specifies whether the user may open pages in Incognito mode in Google Chrome. The possible values are:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Incognito mode disabled (1)
Incognito mode forced (2)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled: Incognito mode disabled (1)

controls:safeguard.title: Explicitly Not Mapped
Explicitly Not Mapped

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Incognito mode in Chrome gives you the choice to browse the internet without your activity being saved to your browser or device.

Allowing users to use the browser without any information being saved can hide evidence of malicious behaviors. This information may be important for a computer investigation, and investigators such as Computer Forensics Analysts may not be able to retrieve pertinent information to the investigation.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled: Incognito mode disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Incognito mode availability
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Users will not be able to initiate Incognito mode for Google Chrome.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Set disk cache size, in bytes' is set to 'Enabled: 250609664'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls the size of the cache, in bytes, used to store files on the disk.
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled: 250609664 or greater

NOTE The value specified in this setting isn't a hard boundary but rather a suggestion to the caching system; any value below a few megabytes is too small and will be rounded up to a reasonable minimum.

controls:safeguard.title: Securely Dispose of Data
Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Having enough disk space for browser cache is important for a computer investigation and for investigators such as Computer Forensics Analysts to be able to retrieve pertinent information to the investigation.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled: 250609664 :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Set disk cache size in bytes
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Browser cache will take up to 250MB in disk space.
